PrefacePreface'Go Green' a series of books on Environmental Education (EVS) is based on 
the EVS syllabus as prescribed by the N.C.E.R.T according to NEP and NCF.
To enable the studen ts to realize their holistic potential in the process of 
learning, we have laid emphasis on the major skills that are to be 
develo ped through EVS. These skills include environmental sensitivit y i.e. 
awar eness, activity, projects, discussio ns scientific skills  and .
For the develo pment of these skills the learners need to be awar e of their 
surroundin gs and becom e keen observer . They should have the spirit of 
enquir y, be able to express their views and exhibit creativity and 
originalit y in doing activities and projects.
Keepin g these needs of t oday's lear ners in mind we ha ve prepared this 
series of EVS books.
These books will also enable the teachers to develo p the skills in studen ts 
as well as assess their learning process.
Any suggestio ns for the betterment of the book shall be thankf ully 
acknowledged and incorporated in the subsequen t editio ns.
Main Points of N EP 2020 & N CF 2023
Creativity Experien tial Lear ning
Life Skills & V alues Communica tionComput ational Thinking Inter-Disciplinar ySubject E nrichm ent Art I ntegration
Critical T hinking Environmental Lit eracy
Problem Solvin g Skills Self M anagement Skills

Let’sKNOW Let’sKNOWOur FamilyUnit–I : We and Our Family
1
Environmental Studies-4 06As you learn t in class 3, a f amily c onsis ts of people who liv e together and ar e 
related to each other . A family can be big or small, joint or nuclear . In this 
chap ter we shall learn about the relations among the member s of a family and 
the chang es that occur in it over a period of time.Starter
A. Paste a pictur e of your family when you were a baby.
B. Paste a pictur e of your family now. 
 Wha t are the differences that you note in your parents and yourself in the 
two pictur es?
The R elation Among the Members of a Family
The member s of a family may be related to each 
other as follows—
  (a) When a boy and a girl marr y each 
other , they form a family . They are 
called husband and wife.

(b) Children born to parents 
become a part of the parent's 
family .
(c) Some people do not have childr en of their 
own. Such people accep t childr en into their 
families who are not born to them. Such 
childr en become a part of the family . This is 
called adop tion.
Changes in a Family
Man y chang es take place in the structur e of a family over a period of time. It may be 
due to some of the reasons given belo w.
! Marriag e– When a son or a daugh ter of a f amily marries, a ne w member in 
the form of a daugh ter-in-la w or son-in-la w joins the family .
! Birth–  When a child is born he/she becomes a part of the family .
! Job transfers  – Some member s of a family migh t have to stay separ ately as 
they get jobs in different cities. This causes chang e in the structur e of a 
family .
If we look at our own families, we will see chang es that have taken place over time. 
Some of our family member s would have grown older or new member s would have 
been born. We all go through this cycle of chang e and growth. Our parents too 
Your Mother as a Child
Have you ever seen the pictur es of your mother when she was a young girl? As a 
young girl, she would have been a good dancer or a good athlete. But, over the 
years, she has chang ed a lot. 
Environmental Studies-407

You  Know Must Mother as a young girl Mother now
We all change as we grow older. Change is a part of our life and we should 
mak e the best of it.She now loves cooking and taking care of the family .
Need of a family
A family is the founda tion of socie ty. We get love, warmth and protection from our 
family . Elder s earn mone y to fulfill our requir emen ts. Without our families, our life 
would become very difficult. 
Extended Family & Family Gatherings
Kirti is the only child of her parents. Thus, she belongs to a small family . Her 
grandpar ents, uncles-aun ts and their childr en are her extended family . They do not 
live under one roof but mee t each other on occasions like wedding , festivals, 
birthda y parties etc. and have fun together.
Maternal Relatives– Kirti's mother belongs to a big family which has her 
grandpar ents, uncles, aunts and cousins. They live together happily . The relatives 
from mother's side are called maternal relatives e.g. grand parents (nana and 
nani), Uncles (mama, mausa), aunts (mami, mausi) and cousins (childr en of mausi 
and mami). The relatives from the father's side are called paternal relatives e.g  
grandpar ents (dada and dadi), uncles (chacha , taya) aunts (bua and chachi) and 
cousins (childr en of chachi, bua and tayi.)(Knowledge )
Environmental Studies-4 08

Family V alues
In the family , we learn a lot of things from each other . Kirti's cousin has taugh t her 
how to play the guitar. She also learn t pain ting from her bua. From our family we 
receiv e moral values also. Some such values are–
! to obey and respect elder s.
! to love each other .
! to always speak the truth.
! to talk polit ely.
! to help people in need.
! to be kind to plan ts and animals.
! to keep the surroundings clean.Kirti's Maternal Family T ree
Environmental Studies-409

! Maternal  – Related to mother
! Paternal   – Related to father

You  Know Must Let’sKNOW Let’sKNOWKnow your Tongue 
and TeethUnit–I : We and Our Family
2
We all have a mouth to eat food and to drink water. In human beings, the 
mouth mainly consists of a tongue and teeth. They both have special ! Which pictur e shows health y teeth?
! Wha t has happened to the teeth in pic-2?
Teeth are an import ant part of our face.
! They give shape to our face.   
! They help to mak e our speech clear .
! They help us to chew our food properlyTeeth
The food that we eat can be digest ed easily only when it is chewed well.
1. 2.Starter
(Knowledge )
Environmental Studies-413

Types of T eeth
Our teeth have different shapes to help us eat different types of food. Some times, 
we need to grind our food and some times, it is to be torn or cut into smaller pieces. 
We have four kinds of teeth in our permanen t set.Human beings grow two sets of teeth during their life time: (A) milk teeth and (B) 
permanen t teeth.
Milk teeth– Babies do not have any teeth in the beginning. The first tooth comes 
out when the baby is about six mon ths old. By the age of two and a half year, the 
baby has a comple te set of 20 teeth. These are called milk teeth. These teeth begin 
to fall by the age of 6, so they are also called tempor ary teeth.
Permanen t teeth– When milk teeth fall off, they are replaced by new and stronger 
teeth. By the age of 12 years, all the milk teeth are replaced by a set of 28 teeth. 
These are called permanen t teeth.
Between the age of 12 and 21, four more teeth grow. These are called wisdom 
teeth. Finally , the adult has a set of 32 permanen t teeth.
1. Incisor s (Biting teeth)– The four front teeth in each jaw are 
called incisor s. Thus, we have eigh t incisor s. They are chisel 
shaped and used for cutting or biting the food.
2. Canines (Tearing teeth)– We have a poin ted tooth called 
canine on either side of the incisor s. Thus, we have four 
canines, two in upper jaw and two in lower jaw. These teeth 
are used to tear the food.
3. Premolar s (Che wing teeth)– After the canines on each side, 
we ha ve tw o fla t and br oad t eeth which ar e used t o crack or 
chew the food. These are called premolar s. They are eigh t in 
number (four in each jaw).
Environmental Studies-4 14

You  Know Must 4. Molar s (Grinding Teeth)– After the premolar s on each 
side, there are three molar s. They are broad with poin ts 
and grooves. Thus, there are twelve molar s (six in each 
jaw) that help in grinding the food.
All these teeth work together to break the food 
into small pieces. This help s us to swallow and 
digest our food easily .
Teeth ar e even har der than our bones.
(Knowledge )
Tooth Decay
Care of T eethWe mus t take care of our teeth. If they are not cleaned properly , a sticky layer of 
food particles is formed on them. Due to this, our teeth look yellow and dirty and 
give out a bad smell. After some time, bact eria grow in our mouth. These bact eria 
produce an acid which mak es holes or cavities in the teeth. This is called tooth 
decay.  
To keep our teeth health y, we should follow some good dental habits–
! We should brush our teeth twice a day, once in the morning and once before 
going to bed.
! We should avoid sticky food like sweets, choc olates, ice-cr eams. They spoil 
our teeth.
! We should eat fresh fruits and leafy vegetables. They mak e our teeth and 
gums strong.
! We should rinse our mouth with water every time we eat some thing.
! We should visit a dentist once in six mon ths.
Environmental Studies-415

Teeth of Animals
Animals also have teeth which help them to chew their food.
Herbiv ores such as cows, horse, camels, deer , sheep etc. have flat teeth in front and 
broad teeth at the back. The front teeth help them to bite grass and leaves of 
plan ts. The back teeth are suited for chewing and grinding. They do not have 
canines because they do not need them.
Carniv ores (flesh eating animals) like lion, tiger, cats, dogs etc. have very sharp 
poin ted canines which they use for tearing the flesh of their prey.Tongue
Our tongue is a muscular organ which help s us to 
move food in the mouth and swallow it. It also 
help s us to speak.
The upper surface of the tongue has tiny bump s 
on it which contain groups of taste buds. Each of 
these taste buds has tiny nerves which send 
messag es to the brain and immedia tely the brain 
tells us wha t we are eating.
The taste buds are located on different parts of the tongue. The tip of the tongue is 
sensitiv e to sweet taste and the back is sensitiv e to bitter taste. The sides of the 
tongue are sensitiv e to sour and salty tastes. Hence, our tongue help s us to iden tify 
four basic tastes-sweet, salty , sour and bitter.
Roden ts (gnawing animals) like rabbit, squirr el, rat etc. gnaw at seeds, fruits and 
nuts. They have two pairs of sharp razor-like teeth to gnaw on nuts and seeds.
Reptiles fish and have all teeth of nearly the same size and shape. They use them to 
catch their prey. They replace their teeth continuously .
Environmental Studies-4 16
